Abstract
A priori calculations of the helium diatom polarizability are combined with an evaluation of the pair distribution function of gaseous helium to yield the second dielectric virial coefficient at 4 and 322°K. Order of magnitude agreement with experimental data is found, but the isotopic dependence at 4°K is in conflict with experimental data

CERTAIN Theoretical Chemistry Institute and Department of Chemistry, University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin 53706, USA and L.W. BRUCH Theoretical Chemistry Institute and Department of Physics, University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin 53706, USA Received 29 April 1974 A priori calculations of the helium diatom polarizability are combined with an evaluation of the pair distribution function of gaseous helium to yield the second dielectric virial coefficient at 4 and 322°K. Order of magnitude agreement with experimental data is found, but the isotopic dependence at 4°K is in conflict with experimental data. Measurements by Orcutt and Cole [ 1 ] and by Kerr and Sherman [2] of the dielectric properties of helium have yielded data for the second dielectric virial coefficient at 322 and 4°K. We report here a priori calculations of the helium diatom polarizability and the consequent second dielectric virial coefficient. Our results are in order of magnitude agreement with the experimental data, but there is a serious discrepancy with the isotopic dependence of the 4°K data. We have concluded that the changes needed in the theory to achieve agreement with the isotopic data are so severe as to be implausible within our understanding of molecular properties. We believe our results modify the interpretation of available experimental data, and that this is a mark of the increasing power of a priori calculations of the molecular properties of helium. The values of BE which we calculate for the helium isotopes at 3 to 5°K have the negative sign and the order of magnitude of the experimental results, but the ordering of the isotopic values is opposite in direction to the experimental values. The values for 4He are calculated to be 2Øo more negative than the values for 3He; the experimental values [2] are 25% more negative for 3He than for 4He. The effect of quantum mechanics for low temperatures is to replace the Boltzmann factor involving the pair potential by the Slater sum or quantum density operator, which we evaluate by the method of Klemm and Storer [6]. At separations within the repulsion of the pair potential, where Ace is very large, the smaller mass of 3He makes g(r) for 3He larger than for 4He, though both are very small'. Just outside the potential barrier, in the region of the van der Waals well, the larger 4I-Ie mass makes g(r) for 4He larger than for 3He, though now Da is smaller in magnitude. These features are apparent in fig. 1. The isotopic dependence is determined by whether the penetration into the potential barrier by 3He is outweighed by the increased density over the well for 4He. The experimental result [2] is that the former effect dominates, while the result of all our model calculations is that the latter effect dominates. The remaining uncertainty in the calculated polarizability arises from the effect of electron correlation. For the helium atom, the correlation correction to the Hartree-Fock polarizability is 0.061 aó;for separations greater than 4a0, we expect the variation in the increment Aa to be less than this. At long range, correlation is known [5] to increase the R-6 coefficient by a factor of four and (cf. table 2) this increases BE of 4He relative to 3He. By increasing the magnitude of the R-6 coefficient, it is possible to achieve a null effect for BE for 3He and 4He. In the region of the potential minimum the contribution of correlation is not known. We adopted several ad hoc models in an attempt to match the isotopic dependence and magnitude of the experimental data at 4 and 322°K. To do this we needed to adjust Aa to remain positive in the region of the potential well (with maximum value ca. O.IOa3), to decrease sharply in the tunnelling region (minimum value ca. -0.30aá), and then to increase again at shorter separations where the pair distribution function for 322°K is much larger than for 4°K. (2b) While the general shape of the resulting Au is not im- plausible, to match the experimental data appears to require that the correlation correction to the in cremental polarizability be an order of magnitude larger than 'AOCHF. Another possible source of the discrepancy at low temperature is the analysis of the data, where relatively high number densities played an important role [2]. At those densities a 2-term virial expansion of the equation-of-state is known to be a poor approximation, and the density coefficient quoted by Kerr and Sherman may be an average slope as distinct from the initial slope which defines BE. We calculated the increment in polarizability for liquid 4He using eq. (2) for Act and a pair distribution function derived from X-ray scattering measurements on the liquid [8] j'. We find BE = -0.033 cm6/mole2 which is comparable to the experimental results. Knowledge of the liquid pair distribution function is limited; for a more stringent test of the calculated polarizability, precise data fi The criticisms of the data made by Lee [9] do not seriously affect our estimates. 235 Volume 27, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 15 July 1974 at lower densities are needed. In summary, with modifications which we believe to be within the present uncertainty (relative to the Hartree-Fock limit) in the calculated Aa we can vary the magnitude of the calculated BE by a factor of 3, but not reverse the isotopic dependence. To achieve agreement with experiment on the isotopic dependence, it is necessary to postulate an electron correlation correction which is an order of magnitude larger than the calculated incremental polarizability. The disagreement with experiment may be a consequence of using too small error assignments in the difficult experiments. A priori calculations of the molecular properties of helium can now make meaningful contributions to the interpretation of experimental data and we believe renewed experimental effort on the dielectric properties of helium is very desirable.
